image.altText: The PwC logo is shown on an office building.

items.synopsis: PricewaterhouseCoopers began work on a top-level consulting contract with the federal government's regulator of tertiary colleges twenty-four hours before agreeing to acquire a $5.5 million stake in one such college, the controversial Top Education Group.

title.children: PwC invested in college while consulting to tertiary education regulator

image.altText: Plastic bags full of meth.

items.synopsis: Federal police have pulled off one of Australia's biggest drug busts, seizing six tonnes of liquid and crystal meth that was hidden in shipments of canola oil bottles destined for Melbourne.

title.children: Charges laid over failed attempt to import $1.7b worth of meth concealed in canola oil bottles

image.altText: Two older ladies in sportswear hold their golf clubs as they walk across the green

items.synopsis: Isabel Sutherland plays two rounds of golf a week and walks about seven kilometres each time. She says it's her key to keeping fit and mobile.

title.children: 'I don't think I'm old': Golf the fountain of youth for 98-year-old Isabel

image.altText: A person with denim jacket and cap seen from behind sitting outdoors at a table looking at phone with laptop open.

items.synopsis: Most cryptocurrencies don't have a head office or a CEO, which makes regulating them tough. But expert Gavin Brown says ignoring their power is not an option.

title.children: 'This is dangerous': This expert says governments have their fingers in their ears about cryptocurrency

image.altText: A man wearing a black cap fixes the collar of Trump's white jumper.

items.synopsis: Many of the familiar faces that surrounded Donald Trump in his final days in the White House have exited his orbit. But there is one man who remained dutifully by his side — and his loyalty may have made him a target of the FBI.

title.children: Before he was Trump's alleged co-conspirator, Walt Nauta was his Diet Coke-wielding 'body man'

image.altText: Side by side photos of Anthony Albanese, looking up in a green tie, and Donald Trump, looking serious in a red tie

items.synopsis: Two years after Anthony Albanese openly criticised Donald Trump, the prime minister is now being urged to prepare for the very real possibility of his return to the White House, writes David Speers.

title.children: Is Albanese prepared for a possible Trump return to the White House?

image.altText: A pregnant woman using a mobile phone

items.synopsis: Many Australians use phone apps to help track their periods, for convenience, contraception or to better understand fertility and reproductive health, but privacy experts warn they're not without risk.

title.children: Many Australians use period-tracker apps for convenience, but experts warn they could come at a cost

image.altText: A white man in a suit and glasses stands at a podium in front of US flags and speaks and gestures with his hands

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: US pauses interest rate rises, Europe's tough AI rules, and no more trips to Hel on the 666 bus. Catch up with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In the US, the Federal Reserve has decided to keep its key interest rate unchanged after 10 consecutive increases. The central bank's move to l eave its benchmark rate at between 5 and 5.25 per cent suggests it believes the much higher borrowing rates it's engineered have made some progress in taming inflation. The Fed has raised its benchmark rate by a substantial five percentage points since March last year — the fastest pace of increases in 40 years. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell says most policy makers expect it'll be appropriate for rates to be raised again this year. "But at this meeting, considering how far and how fast we've moved, we judged it prudent to hold the target range steady, to allow the committee to assess additional information and its implications for monetary policy," he says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US Fed pauses key interest rate after 10 straight increases

props.alt: A white man in a suit and glasses stands at a podium in front of US flags and speaks and gestures with his hands

children.content: (Reuters: Kevin Lamarque)
In the US, the Federal Reserve has decided to keep its key interest rate unchanged
after 10 consecutive increases
The central bank's move to l
eave its benchmark rate at between 5 and 5.25 per cent
suggests it believes the much higher borrowing rates it's engineered have made some progress in taming inflation.
The Fed has raised its benchmark rate by a substantial five percentage points since March last year — the fastest pace of increases in 40 years.
Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell says most policy makers expect it'll be appropriate for rates to be raised again this year.

"But at this meeting, considering how far and how fast we've moved, we judged it prudent to hold the target range steady, to allow the committee to assess additional information and its implications for monetary policy," he says.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A draft law in the European Parliament has become one of the strictest plans to regulate artificial intelligence (AI). European Union lawmakers have agreed on changes to draft AI rules to include a ban on the use of the technology in biometric surveillance, and for generative AI systems like ChatGPT to disclose AI-generated content. The amendments to the EU Commission's proposed landmark law aimed at protecting citizens from the dangers of the technology could set up a clash with EU countries opposed to a total ban on AI use in biometric surveillance. "While Big Tech companies are sounding the alarm over their own creations, Europe has gone ahead and proposed a concrete response to the risks AI is starting to pose," says Brando Benifei, co-rapporteur of the bill. Among other changes, European Union lawmakers want any company using generative tools to disclose copyrighted material used to train its systems and for companies working on "high-risk application" to do a fundamental rights impact assessment and evaluate environmental impact. Systems like ChatGPT would have to disclose that the content was AI-generated, help distinguish so-called deep-fake images from real ones and ensure safeguards against illegal content. The lawmakers will now have to thrash out details with EU countries before the draft rules become legislation.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: EU votes for tougher artificial intelligence regulations

props.alt: Some officials raise their hands to vote during a meeting at the European Parliament in Strasbourg, eastern France

children.content: (AP: Jean-Francois Badias)
A draft law in the European Parliament has become
one of the strictest plans to regulate artificial intelligence
(AI).
European Union lawmakers have agreed on changes to draft AI rules
to include a ban on the use of the technology in biometric surveillance, and for generative AI systems like ChatGPT to disclose AI-generated content.
The amendments to the EU Commission's proposed landmark law aimed at protecting citizens from the dangers of the technology
could set up a clash with EU countries opposed to a total ban on AI use in biometric surveillance

"While Big Tech companies are sounding the alarm over their own creations, Europe has gone ahead and proposed a concrete response to the risks AI is starting to pose," says Brando Benifei, co-rapporteur of the bill.

Among other changes, European Union lawmakers want any company using generative tools to disclose copyrighted material used to train its systems and for companies working on "high-risk application" to do a fundamental rights impact assessment and evaluate environmental impact.
Systems like ChatGPT would have to disclose that the content was AI-generated, help distinguish so-called deep-fake images from real ones and ensure safeguards against illegal content.
The lawmakers will now have to thrash out details with EU countries before the draft rules become legislation.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Independent senator Lidia Thorpe has used parliamentary privilege to accuse a Liberal senator of sexual assault, but later withdrew the remarks. Victorian Liberal David Van was speaking in the Senate about the sex discrimination commissioner's report on parliamentary workplaces when Thorpe started interjecting across the chamber, accusing him of sexually assaulting her. Hours later, Thorpe returned to the chamber to withdraw the comments, citing parliamentary rules, but flagged she would have more to say on the issue. You can keep reading this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: News Australia is searching for: Lidia Thorpe

featuredLink.title: Lidia Thorpe in the Senate accuses Liberal David Van of sexual assault, but later withdraws comments

children.content: Independent senator Lidia Thorpe has used parliamentary privilege to
accuse a Liberal senator of sexual assault, but later withdrew the remarks

Victorian Liberal David Van was speaking in the Senate about the sex discrimination commissioner's report on parliamentary workplaces when Thorpe started interjecting across the chamber, accusing him of sexually assaulting her.
Hours later, Thorpe returned to the chamber to withdraw the comments, citing parliamentary rules, but flagged she would have more to say on the issue.
You can keep reading this story here:

image.altText: A woman with long, dark hair stands in the Senate with her hand in the air as she speaks.

items.synopsis: Lidia Thorpe told the Senate the then prime minister moved Victorian Liberal David Van's parliamentary office after she alleged he had sexually assaulted her.

title.children: Lidia Thorpe in the Senate accuses Liberal David Van of sexual assault, but later withdraws comments

image.altText: Aboriginal people in a NT community - generic image

items.synopsis: Life outcomes for Indigenous Australians are continuing to worsen, as initiatives to Close the Gap offer mixed outcomes in the pursuit of ending systemic disadvantage.

title.children: Government says updated Closing the Gap data highlights need for structural change

image.altText: Xi Jinping smiles and holds a soccer ball while wearing a suit

items.synopsis: The Socceroos' friendly with world champions Argentina raises alarm bells with a warning that Beijing is likely to exploit the match for propaganda.

title.children: 'A birthday gift to Xi': Socceroos match in China raises exploitation concerns

image.altText: A young man sits in a chair donating blood.

items.synopsis: An urgent bloody delivery was made early on Monday to help treat those injured in a bus crash that killed 10 people, including members of the local AFL community. Now, players are working to replenish supplies.

title.children: Hunter Valley Aussie rules community rallies to top up donor blood in wake of wedding bus crash

image.altText: a man with grey haior lying back in a hospital bed

items.synopsis: Darren Belling says the ambulance crew refused to take his wheelchair, which was sent separately in a taxi, and left outside his house for hours.

title.children: 'Stranded': Athlete left at hospital after ambulance refused wheelchair

image.altText: A young girl with red hair tucked into bed, lying on her side and blowing her nose.

items.synopsis: With so much sickness floating around schools and daycare centres, runny noses are a common sight. So, when do your kids need to stay at home, and when can they go to school?

title.children: 'If it's clear, you're in the clear' is common advice when it comes to snot. But is it accurate?

image.altText: Young male migrants standing on a boat waiting for rescue.

items.synopsis: At least 79 migrants drown, with many more said to be missing after their overloaded boat capsized and sank off Greece, in one of Europe's deadliest shipwrecks this year.

title.children: More than 70 killed in Greece's deadliest migrant shipwreck this year

image.altText: A general view of the Harvard Medical School, a square neoclassical building with six large columns.

items.synopsis: The Harvard Medical School morgue manager, his wife and several others face charges over allegations they stole body parts, including heads, brains, skin and bones, that were meant for education and research and sold them to people online for years.

title.children: Network of alleged US cadaver thieves used post to mail body parts around the country

image.altText: Close up of needle vaccination being administered.

items.synopsis: A Tasmanian medical clinic's record-keeping failure has meant 20 years of vaccinations at the facility — including "routine childhood vaccines" — are compromised, with people affected being urged to "discuss revaccination" with their local GP.

title.children: 20 years of vaccinations compromised after Tasmanian medical clinic's record-keeping fail

image.altText: Russian President Vladimir Putin and Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko.

items.synopsis: Alexander Lukashenko says his country has started taking delivery of Russian tactical nuclear weapons, some of which he said were three times more powerful than the atomic bombs the US dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945.

title.children: Belarus starts taking delivery of Russian tactical nuclear weapons

image.altText: A large crowd is pictured surrounding a hearse that's in front of a cathedral.

items.synopsis: Devotees of former Italian prime minister Silvio Berlusconi have flock to Milan to say farewell at a state funeral for the controversial billionaire, which closes a 30-year chapter in the country's history.

title.children: Thousands pay tribute as Silvio Berlusconi is laid to rest

image.altText: Two men in blue shirts look on during a cricket training session.

items.synopsis: England receive a major boost for the opening Ashes Test at Edgbaston with two swing kings joined by Ben Stokes in the bowling attack.

title.children: Ashes boost for England as Stokes declared fit to bowl alongside Broad and Anderson

image.altText: Close-up of man

items.synopsis: Former SAS captain and Liberal MP Andrew Hastie has expressed his relief at Ben Roberts-Smith losing his defamation trial, saying the courage of former colleagues in giving evidence against the Victoria Cross winner had "rescued" the elite regiment.

title.children: 'Cold, hard truth': Hastie breaks silence after Ben Roberts-Smith verdict

image.altText: Paul Frost arrives at the the Downing Centre District Court in Sydney.

items.synopsis: A jury delivers 43 guilty verdicts for a former swim coach and Masterchef finalist who abused 11 children at a south-west Sydney swimming school.

title.children: Swim coach and former MasterChef finalist guilty of 43 child sexual abuse charges

image.altText: Two men dressed in superhero spandex costumes - one red, one blue - stand electrified and ready to fight.

items.synopsis: The troubled actor stars in this regrettable reminder of why the once-thriving DC franchise is wrapping up its extended universe – although Michael Keaton's Batman is (paradoxically) a breath of fresh air.

title.children: DC Comics' The Flash, starring Ezra Miller, is all kinds of confused

image.altText: Win Bakri Daki and Antony Blinken shake hands sitting at a dark timber desk with a man standing behind near US and PNG flags.

items.synopsis: The United States military is being given "unimpeded access" to key PNG defence facilities, including the joint PNG-Australia Lombrum Naval Base on Manus Island, as part of a sweeping Defence Cooperation Agreement.

title.children: US military granted unimpeded access to key Papua New Guinea defence facilities in new security agreement

image.altText: Three police stand next to a road closure sign and witches hat in front of a stretch of bitumen

items.synopsis: Emergency services are responding to the crash about 13 kilometres south-west of the town, where a fire has also broken out.

title.children: Four people injured after freight train collides with truck near Katherine

image.altText: A large black multi-storey building is pictured as it is being demolished.

items.synopsis: South Korea filed a 44.7 billion won ($51 million) damage suit against North Korea on Wednesday for blowing up a joint liaison office just north of their border in 2020, which highlighted a revival of tensions between the rivals following the collapse of larger nuclear talks between the US and North Korea.

title.children: South Korea sues rival North Korea for blowing up joint liaison office in 2020

image.altText: A couple standing together. Man in red cap and woman with dark brown hair

items.synopsis: Simone Strobel's naked body was found in Lismore in 2005. Last year Tobias Moran was charged over her death, but prosecutors have withdrawn their case.

title.children: Charges dropped against man accused of cold case murder of German backpacker Simone Strobel

image.altText: A woman sitting in the dark.

items.synopsis: NSW Police officers need more training to handle domestic violence cases and should not be allowed continue investigating their own colleagues, a new report finds.

title.children: NSW Police officers need more training to deal with domestic violence cases, report finds

image.altText: A police car blocks a road.

items.synopsis: Prosecutors allege the weapons expert who loaded the revolver used on the movie Rust, which resulted in a death, was likely hungover at the time.

title.children: Prosecutors accuse Rust weapons expert in Alec Baldwin case of drinking, smoking marijuana

image.altText: An anonymous outline of a woman with signs from the Hidden Valley community in the background.

items.synopsis: Two women who watched a home go up in flames when a man set fire to it during a fatal domestic violence attack, have re-lived the moment they tried desperately to save people inside, including a toddler.

title.children: Witnesses tell coroner of horrific moment fatal fire was lit in DV attack

image.altText: A large burnt out tingle tree with a hole through it in a forest.

items.synopsis: Prescribed burning is in place to protect homes and habitats. But environmentalists say it is putting fragile forests at risk.

title.children: Conservationists say this is what prescribed burning is doing to WA's iconic wilderness

image.altText: A man in a jacket sits on a park bench.

items.synopsis: Peter Malinauskas apologises to survivors of child sexual abuse in state care during an address to parliament, including Ki Meekins, who was taken interstate and sexually abused in the 1960s.

title.children: 'Given me my identity back': South Australian abuse survivor thanks premier for apology

image.altText: A fictional desert planet called Tatooine in the Star Wars franchise

items.synopsis: An international team of astronomers discovers a rare multi-planet system that closely resembles the home of Star Wars hero Luke Skywalker, Tatooine.

title.children: Astronomers discover rare planet resembling the home of Star Wars' Luke Skywalker
